citation.article-title: Selenihalanaerobacter shriftii gen. nov., sp. nov., a halophilic anaerobe from Dead Sea sediments that respires selenate.

p.s: Description of Selenihalanaerobacter shriftii sp. nov.
Selenihalanaerobacter shriftii (shrif'ti.i, named for the late Alex Shrift, emeritus professor of biology, State University of New York at Binghamton, N.Y.)
Grows by oxidation of glycerol or glucose to acetate+ CO2 with the concomitant reduction of selenate to selenite plus elemental selenium.

Other electron acceptors that support anaerobic growth on glycerol are nitrate and trimethylamine-N-oxide; nitrite, arsenate, fumarate, dimethylsulfoxide, thiosulfate, elemental sulfur, sulfite or sulfate could not serve as electron acceptors.
Glycerol and glucose used as electron donors; no growth observed on short chain fatty acids or alcohols, TCA cycle intermediates, formate, lactate, pyruvate, or several amino acids.
Salinity range for growth: 100–240 g/l, with an optimum at 210 g/l; pH optimum 7.2.
Further properties are as for the genus.
The G+C content of DNA is 31.2 mol%.
Isolated from sediments of the Dead Sea, Israel.
